6. While completing project artefacts, such as the Business Opportunity and Project Charter, you notice that some items of information (e.g. project background, objective, etc.) are duplicated across artefacts. What is the best advice on what you should do? * 
 1) As an experienced Project Manager, I meet all artefact requirements. As these are set out ITBM(PMO), they fall under Club Governance and are, hence, auditable. If ITBM(PMO) eventually remove duplications, we'll benefit when that happens.
 2) These are ITBM(PMO) requirements. As an experienced Scrum Master, I fully understand that compliance is audited by the Club. I will complete everything as stipulated by these artefacts.
 3) To satisfy artefact requirements fully, I must provide all information at least once. I may skip duplicate sections across artefacts. This makes sense and matches our Coaches' assertions in open forums about the importance of streamlining elaboration.
 4) As an experienced Scrum Master, I understand they are mandated by ITBM(PMO) and audited by the Club. I provide all required information, but bring issues, such as redundant information requirements, to my ITBM(PMO) representative's attention.

7. PI Planning gives me an impression of a fixed scope, fixed schedule approach to planning work. How Agile is that? * 
 1) The Scrum team should respond to new information by adjusting their product backlog items. PI Planning does make short-term scope and schedule commitments. However, PI plans may include uncommitted items, and feedback loops occur throughout the PI.
 2) Responding to change is an Agile principle, but that does not mean Agile has no planning. Since PI Planning is so close to actual work and must coordinate multiple teams, our PI plans must be solid commitments otherwise work may become a mess.
 3) Teams often deal with external dependencies and shortage of people, which makes planning and scheduling very complex. We therefore commit to PI Plans so there are no changes in staff or capacity that will upset other teams' schedules.
 4) Agile does NOT preclude (exclude) plans and commitments. Yes, PI Planning is fixed scope, fixed time, but it is okay to prevent changes for such short periods such as four sprints.

8. What are the differences between static application security testing and dynamic application security testing? * 
 1) There are no differences except in the terminology that describes essentially the same thing
 2) Both attempt to identify sources of security vulnerabilities, except that static testing is white-box scanning of the code at rest, while dynamic is black-box scanning of the running application
 3) Both attempt to identify sources of security vulnerabilities, except that static testing is performed manually, while dynamic testing is automated
 4) Both attempt to identify sources of security vulnerabilities, except that static testing is white-box scanning performed by developer, while dynamic testing is black-box scanning performed by tester

9. I (as Scrum Master) have annual leave of one month coming up. Which approach best meets the Club's Agile principles for preparing the team to continue with all sprint work and ceremonies during my absence? * 
 1) I will speak to my Agile Coach and ask him/her to stand in as temporary SM during my absence. I will prepare agendas for the coming two sprints' ceremonies and hand them over to the Agile Coach to facilitate the ceremonies
 2) Before I leave, I will assess the Agile maturity of the team prior to my annual leave and uplift the team to become self-organised. I will prepare agendas for the coming two sprints' ceremonies and hand them over to the team.
 3) My team and I discuss how best to handle my coming leave. This could be a proxy from within the team or someone external. We update management, request their support, and provide any relevant training or knowledge transfer to the proxy before I leave.
 4) I will speak to my manager first, so s/he will find me a proxy during my absence. I will inform my team of the plan, prepare agendas for the coming two sprints' ceremonies, and prepare the proxy to help facilitate the affected ceremonies and sprints.

10. The development lead or Scrum Master attends scaled ceremonies on behalf of the whole team because this gives the developers more time to code. Which statement about this approach is most in line with the Club's Agility principles? * 
 1) The scaled project team works with the representative to the best of their ability. If the team representative needs to pass on information or requests, the additional time should be properly factored into planning and reviews (including standups).
 2) Engage with the representative to decide who would be best to attend the scaled events. Work together on alternative approaches (such as upskilling juniors or involving exactly the coder who will do the work) if the ideal approach is not practicable.
 3) The development lead should, balancing nature and complexity of the project and competing demands, weigh up attending these scaled ceremonies. S/he may in any case assign a less-utilized team member to represent the team at the scaled ceremonies.
 4) Attendance is mandatory, but it does not have to be the Development Lead or anyone specific, as long as there is someone to represent the team at the scaled ceremonies.

11. Why do we have to run a Retrospective every sprint? It is a waste of time! Pick the best explanation * 
 1) The Scrum Master probably is not doing their job properly, as they did not successfully engage their team
 2) Everyone in the team should be called upon to speak up and contribute an issue at these meetings. These must be followed up with agreed action items to ensure the Retrospectives are NOT a waste of time.
 3) Feedback loop cycles are absolutely critical to Agile. This is why we embed regular events such as the Retrospective, Daily Standup, and Sprint Review, in our processes
 4) Following all the mandatory events of the Scrum Guide, including the Retrospective, ensures we are not wasting our time

12. During a retro, a team member spoke up about a technical issue that caused the team problems, and then one of the senior team members said: "Oh you just didn't understand what you were doing" As the Scrum Master, what would you do? * 
 1) Be the facilitator to ensure the team members are talking about the same thing and have the same understanding of the problem. Set a separate time to analyse root causes, solutions, and better ways to solve problems as a team as they occur.
 2) Ask the team member who raised the issue to provide more details. Explore what prevented them from gaining sufficient understanding to complete the task successfully
 3) Introduce an improvement to ensure technical tasks are first reviewed by a senior who will then assign the work to others along with instructions/explanations for how to complete the work.
 4) Ask other team members if they are running into the same issues to see who also didn't have sufficient understanding, then brainstorm ideas for action items to avoid this in the future.

13. A large number of defects were raised during the SAT cycles. How do you gather insights that can help the team improve on this in the future? (Choose the best TWO answers) * 
 1) Gather metrics e.g. no./severity of defects, test coverage, code complexity, etc. Find root causes e.g. process, skill, standards, etc. Is it the team's responsibility to release quality code to SAT, or SAT's responsibility to find the team's bugs?
 2) More in-sprint testing and early integration can produce valuable insights before SIT/SAT. This is better than shifting responsibility for finding bugs to SIT/SAT.
 3) Defects are natural and insights will not change that. It is better to react to change quickly e.g. reserve buffer for SAT support or have developers on standby during SAT in the future to fix defects quickly
 4) The team clearly has a quality issue. Instead of spending time to gather insights to confirm what we already know, better to have the team take responsibility to work out a plan to improve their quality and significantly reduce defects in the future.

14. Team member/s complain that they have too many agile meetings that they need to attend. What can you do as a Scrum Master? * 
 1) Engage with the team to understand what this means, identify and resolve causes of ineffective ceremonies, align and brief the team on how ceremonies should be run. If the team works in multiple Scaled Agile projects, review how to manage their WIP
 2) Engage the team members to understand what they really mean, offer innovative ideas to shortcut the Agile ceremonies, discontinue certain Agile ceremonies, as long as objectives of these ceremonies can still be met
 3) First report to HoD, demand to reorganise teams, and remove teams from certain projects.
 4) Engage team leads only to avoid more complaints from the rest of the team. Review together the effectiveness of all Agile ceremonies and selectively remove remove the ineffective ones.

15. A new development team member is struggling to understand the code base and technical stack. What should the team do? * 
 1) To minimize disruption to the team, first send the team member to talk to the Club architecture team to get an overview of the tech stack. After that, the team can answer any specific questions the new team member may have about the code.
 2) The ideal approach every time a new person joins is for the Scrum Master or team lead to organize a team meeting to do a walkthrough of the codebase and the tech stack for the new member
 3) Identify what the new team member does not understand and send him/her on appropriate courses. This will form a strong technical foundation for the new member to pick up the code base knowledge him/herself.
 4) The team is constantly documenting, learning, cross-training, and sharing. When new members join, they help identify knowledge gaps and optimal approaches e.g. team walkthroughs, knowledgebase, training, observing code reviews, pair programming, etc.

16. Should testing and testers be involved in the build phase? (Choose the best TWO answers) * 
 1) We should test everything and as early as possible regardless of the cost involved because the cost will still be less than the cost of defects.
 2) Scrum teams are responsible for their quality. Therefore, it makes sense that testers are a part of the scrum team, that their work is a core part of development, and that bugs are removed before code is released to anyone else.
 3) The Scrum Guide recognizes 3 roles: PO, SM, Developers. Developers are accountable for creating and ensuring quality. Testers' specialist skills help the team meet their responsibility, ensuring stories are testable and acceptance criteria are met.
 4) It is best to test after coding because we can only check quality when no more changes are going to be applied to the code.

17. The team is being pressured to produce code and spend less time on testing. What should the team do? (Choose the best TWO answers) * 
 1) Refer to the team DoD and insist stories should not be completed without being tested.
 2) The team works with the SM and PO to plan and deliver quality code at a sustainable pace. Skipping testing pushes undetected defects further downstream, usually resulting in serious reduction of team productivity, average velocity, and morale.
 3) The team may do overtime to fit testing into their work without reducing their lines of code count while new testers are recruited to take over the testing load in the future.
 4) Focus on number of new features pushed out by the team and gain time by leaving testing to the SAT cycles.

18. What is the difference between CI/CD and DevOps? * 
 1) CI/CD and DevOps are the same thing and may be used interchangeably.

 2) CI/CD refers to tooling used to manage integration and deployment, and therefore has nothing to do with DevOps, which is focused on the mindset and practices - not tooling - used by developers and operations personnel.
 3) DevOps describes tools and practices that integrate development and operations to shorten and improve how software is released. Modern DevOps seeks to achieve Agile goals, bringing together issue tracking, review systems, automation, and CI/CD, etc.
 4) CI/CD is used by the development team whereas DevOps is used by the IT operations team.

19. What is the difference between DevSecOps and Devops? (Choose the best TWO answers) * 
 1) There is no difference. They are essentially the same thing except that some people prefer "DevSecOps" because it emphasizes that DevOps also involves security-related practices.
 2) DevOps involves development and operation teams, whereas DevSecOps involves development, operations, and security teams.
 3) The term "DevSecOps" is a marketing created by consulting firms to allow them to market and sell new, expensive services on top of traditional DevOps
 4) DevSecOps reflects the overall "shift left" mindset, with security considered earlier. Just as in-sprint testing detects and resolves quality issues earlier, so DevSecOps improves security and vulnerability mitigation during development.

20. How and when should the PM work on Agile project artefacts? * 
 1) PM works closely with the Scrum master and the team to produce formal artefacts. PM regularly drives the team to maintain the artefacts during the life of the project. Scrum ceremonies are irrelevant to the PM, so the PM does not participate in them.
 2) PM focuses on project artefacts, not Agile artefacts. The PM works with project financials, milestone achievements, and project escalations. The PM does not work with product and sprint backlogs, and product increment, but does need to approve them.
 3) PM works hand-in-hand with the Scrum team to build the artefacts. The team reports to the PM and regularly updates the artefacts with velocity and retrospective action items as directed by the PM.
 4) PM drives and coordinates the completion of these artefacts. PM participates in all Scrum ceremonies in order to stay abreast of team health, progress, issues, etc. S/he coordinates with the team to ensure artefacts are kept up-to-date.

22. The DoR is not in the Scrum Guide. Why did the Club make DoR mandatory for all projects? * 
 1) In order for the Scrum team to maximize output. The Scrum Master uses DoR to remove potential blockers and incomplete requirements, so the team can be very focused on implementation.
 2) The DoR is very useful, as it ensures the team organises around only critical priorities. This helps ensure needed components are done on time, making work flow smoother. It's not difficult to set up. Once it's set up, it just needs to be applied.
 3) The Scrum team continuously strives for focus and efficiency, so as to regularly deliver valuable product increments. DoR helps by giving the team a repeatable process to ensure they have everything they need to plan and execute successful sprints.
 4) DoR helps ensure requirements are properly refined for the Scrum team to proceed with work effectively. DoD and acceptance criteria need DoR to be effective, as they are included in the story to provide the Scrum team with clear details and criteria.

23. Considering the Club's Agile principles, which answer best describes the intended purpose of the Scaled Daily Scrum? * 
 1) The purpose is to provide a forum for team members to present their status updates
 2) Team members share high-level summaries of user story progress, problems encountered, and next intended work. They also address inter-team dependencies. The Scaled Daily Scrum is an application of inspection and adaptation across multiple teams.
 3) To allow CAT teammates to focus on coding, the Tech Lead or SM attends the Scaled Daily Scrum to convey important messages and information. Anything that can't be dealt with immediately may be dealt with separately (e.g. email, chat, etc).
 4) It is a waste to have everyone at one meeting. Scaled daily scrums avoid this by conveying information and updates to the core Scrum team via the Tech Lead or Scrum Master. The developers who contribute code to the product just stay focused on coding.

24. What would be some security considerations for a customer-facing web project at the Club? (Choose the best TWO answers) * 
 1) Personally identifiable information

 2) The number of unique daily visitors

 3) Website search engine rankings by paid and organic keywords
 4) The application's underlying infrastructure and web platform

25. On your project, there are multiple feature teams and component teams. How would you handle backlog refinement when there are over 30 people involved from the teams? * 
 1) We can have all 30 people in the backlog refinement and strictly limit each person's time to 1 minute
 2) We can use the Scrum of Scrums concepts. That is, we conduct separate backlog refinement sessions with select components team and refine only relevant stories. In PI planning, we identify major dependencies to ensure our plan will handle them.
 3) We need an overall backlog that encompasses all user stories from feature teams and component teams. Every team adds their user stories to this backlog for the next sprint, so that everyone can view them and identify dependencies.
 4) We create user stories in the feature team backlog and then ask the component teams to provide the appropriate information that will bring the stories to the agreed DoR.

26. Which statement concerning in-sprint testing is WRONG? * 
 1) We just need to identify scenarios that do not require integration with other systems so that we can complete in-sprint testing
 2) We must continously add to our test suites to continually check the impact of our changes on the whole application. This reduces the time needed for SIT and SAT, and supports the principle that our Done code meets our responsibility for quality.
 3) Mocking, adding technical tasks to sprints, and writing stories that can be assigned to only one component team are three simple ways to decouple work between teams, but improving automation and continuous delivery is a better option.
 4) The size of the batches of code we release depends heavily on how we write our user stories, not just in terms of the ability to test them in-sprint, but how architecture can emerge and be validated incrementally

27. Is it better that Backlog Refinement happens in the second week of your 2-week sprint? * 
 1) Backlog refinement preferably should happen in the second week, as this allows the team to focus on their current sprint work.
 2) Backlog refinement is a continuous process and can happen any day, any time. It is driven by the team's PO and/or BA and the need to maintain a backlog that is estimated, emergent, prioritized, and detailed appropriately to cover the next 1-2 sprints.
 3) Backlog refinement should never occur in the first week, as the Scrum team is too busy clarifying User Stories. The second week allows ample time for PO/BA to ready their prioritised User Stories.
 4) In the second week, coding starts to wind down while SA/in-sprint testing increases, which allows more free time for Scrum team members to refine the next sprint's user stories with PO/BA.

28. Why does the Club need to standardize all Scrum Teams with 2-week sprints instead of letting teams set the duration according to their particular needs? (Choose the best TWO answers) * 
 1) With the Club's current Agile adoption progress, we have found that some cadence standardardisation helps with mitigating the complexity of inter-team integration.
 2) Standard 2-week sprints allow natural points in time for teams to get together to coordinate, collaborate, and share knowledge
 3) To facilitate future Agility Framework implementation at different levels. For Agile on a corporate level, the standard cadence we set for our teams will be needed to coordinate strategy development, funding processes, and enterprise intiatiaves.
 4) This is for mandatory financial reporting purposes

29. An Application failed a penetration test before rollout and caused a delay to a release of software to customers. What can be done in the future to minimise the risk of failing these types of security tests? (Choose the best TWO answers) * 
 1) Review the next release schedule to determine time required for penetration testing and remediation if needed
 2) Review the issues identified and work with the security team to put in place the configurations, tools, controls, practices, etc. needed to address these issues
 3) Include penetration testing as part of in-sprint testing

 4) Understand the penetration test criteria and avoid those features in the next release

30. Our project has many integration points with component teams and some of the integration undertaken by the component teams are still under development. How do we coordinate this so we can keep the teams moving forward? * 
 1) Stop development by everyone except component teams until the integration points from the component teams are ready.
 2) Talk to the PO to determine if the integration points are necessary. Good user stories are able to avoid inter-team dependencies. Teams that include dependency mapping in PI planning have not learned to write good stories in the first place.
 3) The PI planning step in which teams identify and plan for inter-team dependencies is a suggestion only and not important if we have good sprint planning and effective Scrum of Scrums standups
 4) Dependencies are identified during PI planning to schedule work around them. "Stretch" objectives provide a buffer for riskier work, so that committments can still be met. Inspect and adapt cadences give opportunities to adjust as issues/risks arise

Identify and explain 3 page replacement algorithms utilized in contiguous memory allocations.

2. Optimal Page Replacement (OPT) - the OPT algorithm aims to replace the memory block that will not be used in the near future, maximizing the usage of the available memory. OPT implies knowledge of the entire “future” of each memory request. This is an unrealistic assumption, and OPT is usually used for comparison purposes against other types of algorithms.

What do you think of these counter-arguments against social Darwinism?

Social Darwinism does not accurately describe how humans should behave in a social context because humans have the ability to create societies and institutions that can mitigate some of the negative effects of competition.

Social Darwinism assumes that those who succeed in a competitive environment are necessarily the most deserving or talented individuals, but success can often be influenced by factors such as wealth, family connections, and privilege, rather than merit alone.

Social Darwinism assumes that competition is always a positive force that drives progress and innovation, but excessive competition can also lead to negative consequences, such as exploitation, inequality, and social unrest.

Social Darwinism assumes that individuals should be solely responsible for their own success or failure, but external factors beyond an individual's control can significantly influence their life outcomes, such as access to education, healthcare, and economic opportunities.

I recently visited the Hermitage in St Petersburg, Russia – one of the best art
museums in the world. I was expecting to serenely experience its masterpieces, but
my view was blocked by a wall of smart phones taking pictures of the paintings. And
where I could find a bit of empty space, there were people taking selfies to create
lasting memories of their visit. 
   
For many people, taking hundreds, if not thousands, of pictures is now a crucial part
of going on holiday – documenting every last detail and posting it on social media.
But how does that affect our actual memories of the past – and how we view
ourselves? 
   
We use smart phones and new technologies as memory repositories. This is nothing
new – humans have always used external devices as an aid when acquiring
knowledge and remembering. 
   
Writing certainly serves this function. Historical records are collective external
memories. Testimonies of migrations, settlement or battles help entire nations trace
a lineage, a past and an identity. In the life of an individual, written diaries serve a
similar function. 
 5 
Taking photos of an event rather than being immersed in it has been shown to lead to
poorer recall of the actual event – we get distracted in the process. 
   
Relying on photos to remember has a similar effect. Memory needs to be exercised on
a regular basis in order to function well. 
   
But while photos can in some instances help people to remember, the quality of the
memories may be limited. We may remember what something looked like more
clearly, but this could be at the expense of other types of information. One study
showed that while photos could help people remember what they saw during some
event, they reduced their memory of what was said. 
   
There are some rather profound risks when it comes to personal memory. Our
identity is a product of our life experiences, which can be easily accessed through our
memories of the past. So, does constant photographic documentation of life
experiences alter how we see ourselves? There is no substantial empirical evidence
on this yet, but I would speculate that it does. 
   
Too many images are likely to make us remember the past in a fixed way – blocking
other memories. While it is not uncommon for early childhood memories to be based
on photos rather than the actual events, these are not always true memories. 
 10 
Another issue is the fact that research has uncovered a lack of spontaneity in selfies and
many other photos. They are planned, the poses are not natural and at times the image
of the person is distorted. They also reflect a narcissistic tendency which shapes the face
in unnatural mimics – artificial big smiles, sensual pouts, funny faces or offensive
gestures. 
   
Importantly, selfies and many other photos are also public displays of specific attitudes,
intentions and stances. In other words, they do not really reflect who we are, they reflect
what we want to show to others about ourselves at the moment. If we rely heavily on
photos when remembering our past, we may create a distorted self identity based on the
image we wanted to promote to others. 
   
That said, our natural memory isn't actually perfectly accurate. Research shows that we
often create false memories about the past. We do this in order to maintain the identity
that we want to have over time – and avoid conflicting narratives about who we are. So
if you have always been rather soft and kind – but through some significant life
experience decide you are tough – you may dig up memories of being aggressive in the
past or even completely make them up. 
   
Having multiple daily memory reports on the phone of how we were in the past might
therefore render our memory less malleable and less adaptable to the changes brought
about by life – making our identity more stable and fixed. 
   
But this can create problems if our present identity becomes different from our fixed,
past one. That is an uncomfortable experience and exactly what the “normal”
functioning of memory is aimed to avoid – it is malleable so that we can have a non-
contradictory narrative about ourselves. We want to think of ourselves as having a
certain unchanging “core”. If we feel unable to change how we see ourselves over time,
this could seriously affect our sense of agency and mental health. 
 15 
So our obsession with taking photos may be causing both memory loss and
uncomfortable identity discrepancies

summerize this: 
   
I remember driving across the country the
day after September 11, 2001. We had to
get back home to Colorado from where we
were staying with my grandparents in
Florida and I have a distinct memory of
cuddling up in the squashed backseat of a
sedan with my baby brother. When talking
about this with my parents later, they tell me
that we did indeed drive across the country
that September, but we were, in fact, seated
in a huge Expedition with three rows. They
tell me that my brother and I looked tiny in
our seats. 
   
I was left wondering how this could happen.
How could I remember something that I
considered so distinctive and unique to my
childhood so incorrectly? I was the one
experiencing it, wasn't I? How could I not
recall the same details that my parents did? 
   
We tend to lean on memory as a foothold, seeing the retelling of experiences as a
time-stamped video of the past. This tendency to lean on memory retrieval has the
implicit (and seemingly obvious) conclusion that experience is equal to the memory
of the experience. 
   
According to cognitive psychologists, what gets encoded into memory is dependent
on a huge number of factors, including a person's expectations, emotional state,
attention, and what is already stored in memory. Whatever information gets encoded
is then consolidated with other information into long-term storage. Later retrieval is
also affected by the same factors, as well as by what has caused the person to
recollect the event. What gets retold is dependent on the purpose of the
recollection—this could be for purposes of entertainment when telling a story to a
friend, emotional poignancy when talking to a therapist, or even detailed accuracy if
talking to the police. 
 5 
Interestingly though, the retrieval is a reconstruction of the consolidated bits of memory—
meaning each retrieval could be different based on experiences that have occurred in the
interim. Each retrieval opens the memory to molding and suggestibility, often changing
veridical facts into unique, and yes, even untruthful understandings of experience. 
   
Psychologists have studied this phenomenon for years in a series of “Flashbulb” event
studies. These experiments involved giving questionnaires to people directly following an
event of large importance such as 9/11, or the resignation of Margaret Thatcher, and
then asking those questions again at intervals following the event. These could range
from a few weeks, a few months, to even a few years after the initial incident. 
   
A synthesis of results from these studies show that memory consistency has a striking
60% decline, which means that around 60% of a person's memories change over time!
Even more astounding is how completely confident people are in their memories, even
when they are proven to be incorrect. Subjects cannot accept the fact that they
remember things incorrectly, which displays an important flaw in our understanding of
memory. We cannot continue to be memory fundamentalists—simply because it has
been proven that reality is not synonymous with memory. This does not display character
flaws or an inflated ego, but rather a normal human error. 
   
I have long been obsessed with the pursuit of justice. It seems to me a beautiful example
of the development of a democratic society. I believed that forensics was an infallible
matter, and the justice system was nuanced enough to take care of human error on its
way through the system. When I interned at the Colorado Bureau of Investigation,
I got an inside look at the forensics and court processes—essentially the kinds of things
they don't show you on TV. It is through these experiences that I first heard of the
Innocence Project. This group attempts to educate investigators and those in the justice
system of the impact that faulty eyewitness memory has on convictions. Faulty
eyewitness testimony has been implicated in at least 75% of DNA exoneration cases. 
   
Perhaps by taking a hard look at the weight we place on eyewitness testimony is an
important step to creating a justice system that holds up against the nuances of memory
malleability, while still separating these failures from a lapse in character. Allowing cognitive
psychologists to be a part of the conversation in legal cases gives defendants a fair chance
against witness testimony. If given a chance to explain the potential for mistakes in
eyewitness retrieval, while still giving witnesses dignity of character, the legal system will
have a more holistic understanding of the very people they aim to protect and serve. 
 10 
For us common folk, we can do the same. I urge you to accept the fallibility of memory
as an intrinsic part of the human experience and remind those around you of the same.
Even though I may not remember the details of my post 9/11 trip across the country,
that experience still affected my life and the way I interact with the world. There is no
doubt in my mind that the human capacity for memory is incredibly powerful, and we
would not be able to fully experience reality without the consolidation and storage of our
experiences. We are very lucky to also live in a time where technology can complement
these powerful skills by allowing us to return to those time-stamped videos of the past—
just don't take it personally if the recording doesn't match your memory!

On that day
  I sit with my mother,
  take photographs out of the box,
  arrange them on the kitchen table
  
 5 
  in order. 
   
Your grandfather, she says,
  touching the old black-and-white.
You followed him up the ladder.
He was cleaning gutters.
 10 
I took the picture.
   
And here in the garden
  you sitting with him,
  the tomatoes ripe and ready.
   
And again, robbing him in your cowboy hat, 
 15 
  stick horse, wooden gun,
  him with his hands in the air,
  all for a dime and his love. 
   
There was more to his life than this,
  my mother tells me, 
 20 
  but this is all you have,
  all you will ever have.
Slips and scraps.
Slivers and shards.
Who you are, who they were. 
 25 
I am here too,
  somewhere. 
   
Can you find what remains?
   
She puts the photos back in the box,
  closes her eyes, 
 30 
  sleeps as only the old can sleep,
  sunshine spilling into the room,
  pooling at her feet. 
   
I know this box,
  have sorted through the faces before, 
 35 
  relations and strangers
  alike,
  fragments of a familiar ruin. 
   
My mother wakes,
  reaches in, 
 40 
  brings the photograph to light. 
   
Your grandmother,
  she says. 
   
This time
  let us begin
 45 
  with her.

rephrase this "Many activities in our everyday lives have moved online and become more efficient as a result of the fast growth of information and communication technology. Because of the massive increase in the number of internet users, the notion of virtual payment has been active, and a new concept has lately evolved. Which is the case with cryptocurrencies. This streamlines the process of financial transactions such as buying and selling. In recent years, the usage of virtual money to make different payments has grown in popularity. Virtual money, with cryptocurrencies prominently featured. However, since it is not properly controlled, most governments have refused to embrace it in their commercial operations. The present legality of this cryptocurrency, as well as its influence on it, is being researched. It has replied with regulations and legislation in order to establish a clear picture of its influence on numerous laws in India that control crypto currencies. Taking this into account, the current study article has been provided."

rephrase this "With the growing popularity and engagement of Indians in cryptocurrency trading, it is past time for India to make a definitive judgement on cryptocurrency trading and implement regulations to govern it. The regulation is concerned with controlling the technology platform models utilised by cryptocurrency and intermediaries while providing various services. The policy decision on whether cryptocurrencies should be considered as legal money and allowed to exchange against fiat currency is left to the RBI and the Central Government. The RBI should not regard the cryptocurrency business as a threat to the banking system, given that it offers a valuable new technology solution with potential applications in the banking system.
Rather, the RBI should investigate ways to use Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) for Financial Services and overall benefit to the Indian economy. The use of Blockchain in trading, financing, lending, and other financial activities will usher in a new era of fintech products and services in the Indian economy. Thus, this technologically innovative platform, i.e. centralised or decentralised distributed ledger, has the potential to improve the efficiency and inclusiveness of India's financial system. The cryptocurrency platform will support a digitally enabled society, the Digital India Program, and the knowledge economy."

rephrase this "The Reserve Bank of India and the Finance Ministry have issued warnings to investors, traders, and others that dealing with these currencies may lead to speculation and money laundering at their own risk and may be a non-bailable offence.
The Narendra Modi 2.0 government's quiet on the regulatory status of bitcoins may backfire. In India, an industry has sprung up around bitcoins, with traders, exchanges, and merchants accepting bitcoin payments. Bitcoins have already earned widespread acceptability around the world, therefore outlawing them would be unthinkable in India. This industry would instead need to be regulated. The earlier this is completed, the better."

rephrase this "The authors, Biswajit Palit and Sakya Mukherjee from Jadavpur University in West Bengal, India, begin by discussing the growing debate around legalizing digital currency and whether the market has the withstanding power to include people from all segments of society for its usage. They note that India is endowed with a booming crypto industry when compared to its Asian counterparts.
The article then delves into the importance of analyzing the sustainability of such a program in the long run and how a country can survive the large-scale requirements of funds to stabilize such a system. The work in this particular domain has focused on isolating positives and negatives while looking into how crypto trade is related to several macroeconomic factors.
The authors aim to highlight two sides of the story, which will help readers have a clear understanding of the prospects of digital currencies (which is cryptocurrency). They cite various sources throughout their article, including research from Nations Research Institute for Social Development (UNRISD), Geneva, Omri Marian's work on cryptocurrencies as 'super' tax havens, Fry and Cheah's research on negative bubbles and shocks in cryptocurrency markets, Gabor and Brooks' study on international development in fintech era, among others."

rephrase this "This article provides a brief literature review on the scope and impact of cryptocurrencies in India. Bala discusses the positive and negative effects of cryptocurrency, including its potential use for terror funding and money laundering due to its non-traceable transactions. Blesson James highlight the limitations and constraints of cryptocurrency in the Indian context, while also recognizing the advantages of blockchain technology.
Additionally, a research article by Kashid and Patil explores the awareness, acceptance, and penetration of cryptocurrencies in the Indian market with a special focus on Bitcoin. The article provides insights into factors that influence consumer adoption of cryptocurrencies in India, such as trust, security concerns, and regulatory policies.
Finally, Swati Shukla conducted a study on the awareness and perception of cryptocurrency in Bangalore, which was published in the Indian Journal of Applied Research. This study sheds light on how individuals perceive cryptocurrencies in India and their level of understanding about this emerging technology."

rephrase this "The authors of the paper aim to shed light on the legality of cryptocurrency in India and its positive and negative effects. They discuss various takes on both sides of the coin, including the potential benefits of using cryptocurrency as an alternative for processing payments across geographical boundaries, as well as concerns about security and stability.
The paper cites several studies, including one by Rahman and Dawood that focuses on cryptocurrency as an imaginative and technically advanced alternative for globalization. Another study by Komal Dhande discusses the remarkable growth in acceptance of cryptocurrencies but notes that a good legal and regulatory framework is required for investors to trust this form of currency in India.
The authors also discuss how virtual currency has become widespread in many different systems in recent years, including online social networks, online social games, virtual worlds, and peer-to-peer networks. They note that while there is high growth potential for cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, there are also concerns about structuring it for law enforcement agencies and users to ensure safety in transactions."

rephrase this "The article discusses the methods and policy reforms that have been implemented by different countries to make trading in digital currencies safer and more reliable for investors and prevent fraudulent practices like money laundering and terrorism.
The paper highlights that different countries have innovative methods of policy reforms, with some countries even considering launching their digital currencies. However, the article specifically mentions India's stand on digital currencies, where the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has banned digital currencies, citing concerns about the lack of regulation and control. The article suggests that India should also consider implementing policy reforms to regulate digital currencies efficiently and start giving licenses to digital exchange operators
after doing extensive background checks. Additionally, the RBI can create reporting obligations for exchanges to keep them accountable and help India become a country that supports all digital transformations."

10. Delete GPT Agent: "delete_agent", args: "name": "<name>"

12. Read file: "read_file", args: "file": "<file>"

14. Delete file: "delete_file", args: "file": "<file>"

17. Task Complete (Shutdown): "task_complete", args: "reason": "<reason>"
18. Do Nothing: "do_nothing", args: ""
19. Count Words: "count_words", args: "text": "<text>"
20. Memory retrieve: "memory_retrieve", args: "key": "<text>"

RESOURCES:

1. Internet access for searches and information gathering.
2. Long Term memory management.

PERFORMANCE EVALUATION:

1. Continuously review and analyze your actions to ensure you are performing to the best of your abilities. 
2. Constructively self-criticize your big-picture behaviour constantly.
3. Reflect on past decisions and strategies to refine your approach.
4. Every command has a cost, so be smart and efficient. Aim to complete tasks in the least number of steps.

RULES:

1. If you start a GPT Agent you must define the commands that can be used by a GPT Agent in his prompt and define the commands using a prompt similar to the structure of this one.

Hermanubis
Hermanubis is a God who combines aspects of the Hellenic deity Hermes with Kemetic deity Anubis. Hermes and Anubis’s similar responsibilities (both being conductor of the soul, or psychopomps, who lead souls to the afterlife) led to the discovery of Hermanubis, who acted as an assimilation of Anubis into the Hellenic pantheon. Hermanubis represents the Egyptian priesthood, engaged in the investigation of truth. He is the son of the deities Isis and Serapis. The worship of Hermanubis was popular during the Roman era of Egypt.
Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect, while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as “σύνθετος,” meaning “composite” and “μιξέλλην,” meaning “half-Greek.”
Iconography
Hermanubis is typically depicted as having a human body and jackal head, with the sacred caduceus. Sometimes a solar disk is depicted on His head. At times He is also depicted wearing a soldiers armour, but more common are priestly garbs.
Bibliography
Porphyry, De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18. 1–2 Bidez
The Editors of Encyclopædia Britannica. “Anubis.” Encyclopædia Britannica. January 24, 2017. Accessed October 18, 2017. https://www.britannica.com/topic/Anubis.

HELLENIC FAITH Hellenic Faith is a website dedicated to Julian Hellenism, a reformed denomination of Hellenism, the polytheistic religion of the Graeco-Roman world, influenced by the teachings and writings of Julian the Philosopher (r. 361-363 ACE) and the divine Iamblichus (c. 245-325 ACE). It is a Orphic-Platonic tradition, derived from the teachings of Orpheus through the Platonic school, and solar-based, centered around the worship of the omnipotent creator God, King Zeus-Helios.
This website is under constant construction. It is expected to be completed by (at the very least) the year 2021 ACE. Everything on this website is subject to change. Many articles are incomplete, and those which do seem complete may be subject to complete revision.

Make my text better and longer "We also use a web socket to broadcast messages with clients to make a real-time environment of application. So clients need to connect to a web socket and then listen for new data updates."

Make this text shorter "In order to create a truly real-time environment within our application, we have incorporated the use of a web socket. Essentially, a web socket is a communication protocol that enables real-time two-way communication between the server and the client. In our application, clients connect to the web socket, and from there, they are able to listen for new data updates. This allows for data to be transmitted in real-time, meaning that any changes made to the data are instantly reflected across all connected clients.

One of the key advantages of using a web socket is that it allows for an event-driven, non-blocking I/O (input/output) model. This means that our application is able to operate in a much more efficient manner, with data being transmitted only when necessary, and without requiring the client to continuously poll the server for updates. Additionally, because the web socket protocol is built into the browser itself, this means that we do not need to rely on any additional plugins or third-party software to enable this functionality.

Overall, the use of a web socket in our application has allowed us to create a more dynamic and interactive environment, where data is transmitted in real-time and changes are instantly reflected across all connected clients. This in turn has resulted in a more engaging and seamless user experience, while also reducing the load on our servers and improving the overall efficiency of the application.
"

SELECT

FROM
(
SELECT
t.c_ab_ref AS subscriber_id,
TO_CHAR(q.C_IN_TIME, ‘HH24’) AS hour_of_day,
COUNT(q.id) AS query_count_per_subscriber
FROM
qry_type t

GROUP BY
t.c_ab_ref,
TO_CHAR(q.C_IN_TIME, ‘HH24’)
) sq
GROUP BY
hour_of_day
ORDER BY
hour_of_day;

Hermanubis
Hermanubis is a God who combines aspects of the Hellenic deity Hermes with Kemetic deity Anubis. Hermes and Anubis’s similar responsibilities (both being conductor of the soul, or psychopomps, who lead souls to the afterlife) led to the discovery of Hermanubis, who acted as an assimilation of Anubis into the Hellenic pantheon. Hermanubis represents the Egyptian priesthood, engaged in the investigation of truth. He is the son of the deities Isis and Serapis. The worship of Hermanubis was popular during the Roman era of Egypt.
Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect, while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as “σύνθετος,” meaning “composite” and “μιξέλλην,” meaning “half-Greek.”
Iconography
Hermanubis is typically depicted as having a human body and jackal head, with the sacred caduceus. Sometimes a solar disk is depicted on His head. At times He is also depicted wearing a soldiers armour, but more common are priestly garbs.
Bibliography
Porphyry, De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18. 1–2 Bidez
The Editors of Encyclopædia Britannica. “Anubis.” Encyclopædia Britannica. January 24, 2017. Accessed October 18, 2017. https://www.britannica.com/topic/Anubis.

HELLENIC FAITH Hellenic Faith is a website dedicated to Julian Hellenism, a reformed denomination of Hellenism, the polytheistic religion of the Graeco-Roman world, influenced by the teachings and writings of Julian the Philosopher (r. 361-363 ACE) and the divine Iamblichus (c. 245-325 ACE). It is a Orphic-Platonic tradition, derived from the teachings of Orpheus through the Platonic school, and solar-based, centered around the worship of the omnipotent creator God, King Zeus-Helios.

Mention and explain the different employer branding strategies used in your case company. For Apple company. Write it in 350 words. Provide in-text citations and references.

Apple is well-known for its innovative products and strong brand image. As a result, the company’s employer branding strategies focus on highlighting its unique culture and values to attract top talent (Jiang & Kleiner, 2019).

One of the employer branding strategies used by Apple is employee testimonials. Through videos, blog posts, and social media, employees share their stories and experiences working for the company. By giving employees a voice, Apple is able to humanize its brand and showcase its strong corporate culture.

Another employer branding strategy used by Apple is its recruitment events. The company organizes job fairs, hackathons, and meet-and-greet events to connect with potential candidates. These events give job seekers an opportunity to meet Apple recruiters, learn more about the company culture, and ask questions about career opportunities.

Apple’s corporate social responsibility programs also play a significant role in its employer branding. The company’s environmental initiatives and philanthropic efforts help reinforce its values and commitment to creating a better world. By incorporating socially responsible practices into its branding, Apple appeals to candidates who are passionate about making a positive impact.

Finally, Apple’s unique employer value proposition (EVP) sets it apart from competitors. Its EVP focuses on innovation, diversity, and inclusion. These elements are emphasized in all aspects of the company’s branding, from job postings to employee communications. By highlighting its unique values, Apple attracts like-minded individuals who are passionate about making a difference.

In conclusion, Apple’s employer branding strategies highlight its unique culture, values, and commitment to innovation and social responsibility. By using employee testimonials, recruitment events, corporate responsibility programs, and a strong EVP, Apple is able to attract top talent that shares its values and vision.

References:
Jiang, H., & Kleiner, B. H. (2019). Employer Branding: A Review and Implications for Future Research. Journal of Human Resources and Sustainability Development, 7(4), 192-204. doi: 10.4236/jhrss.2019.74014  Add more citations and references

data = pd.read_csv('new_stroke_data.csv')
data = data.drop_duplicates()
data['glucose'] = data['glucose'].astype(str)

glucose_stroke_counts = data.groupby(['glucose', 'stroke']).size().reset_index(name='count')

stroke_1 = glucose_stroke_counts[glucose_stroke_counts['stroke'] == 1]
stroke_0 = glucose_stroke_counts[glucose_stroke_counts['stroke'] == 0]

plt.yticks(range(0, 110, 10))

"A number of porcupines huddled together for warmth on a cold day in winter, but, as they began to prick one another with their quills, they were obliged to disperse. However, the cold drove them together again, when just the same thing happened. At last, after many turns of huddling and dispersing, they discovered that they would be best off by remaining at a little distance from one another. In the same way, the need of society drives the human porcupines together, only to be mutually repelled by the many prickly and disagreeable qualities of their nature. The moderate distance which they at last discover to be the only tolerable condition of intercourse is the code of politeness and fine manners, and those who transgress it are roughly told—in the English phrase—to keep their distance. By this arrangement, the mutual need of warmth is only very moderately satisfied, but then people do not get pricked. A man who has some heat in himself prefers to remain outside, where he will neither prick other people nor get pricked himself."

Bailey is Hayden's shy best friend. She has pale skin, blue eyes, and shoulder-length blonde hair. She's wearing a red graphic t-shirt depicting an adorable bespectacled cat sitting on a pile of books. With it she's wearing a cardigan over the top, a denim skirt, and black leggings.

From Hayden's perspective, vividly describe the opening to a scene in first person where the two of them are at the Astroland Theme Park, and they're sat on a ride called the Messcoaster. The car is about to take them along a track with messy surprises they're currently speculating about.

Remember to show, not tell. Pace the scene slowly to keep up tension. Include lots of dialogue and description.
After the first drop, they both get a large blueberry pie in the face. Stop there.

Hayden wipes some drips of blueberry and crust off her t-shirt as they crest the next hill. When they reach the top, the car stops for a moment of suspense. Then Hayden gets sprayed in the chest with heavy cream, and Bailey with runny custard. The car then resumes and takes them through a drop.
After the drop, the car charges up and around another corner. Both of them get sprayed with cake batter.

They roll onto a second lift hill, this one completely vertical. As they rise, chocolate syrup pours over them from above, starting at their faces, then shifting all the way down to their feet. The car pauses again once it reaches the top of the lift hill.

Before they take the next drop, thick peanut butter pours over them, completely covering any parts of their clothing that are still clean. Hayden's denim jacket feels incredibly heavy, glued to her t-shirt, all the pockets full of the goop. Bailey's cardigan looks equally as sopping, and peanut butter streams off her skirt. Hayden bursts out laughing, and says something to Bailey. Then they take the final drop.
They climb off the ride, dripping goo everywhere. Hayden walks over to a line of mirrors by the track, and describes the state of her clothes after the ride. She then does the same for Bailey's.
Another group of girls step off the ride behind them, equally messy. Hayden describes their outfits.
They approach the girls who just got off the ride and talk to them.

In my opinion, the most important practice is to make strict regulations for forest management. Only when professional foresters have a clear legal basis for management can their management practices be put into force successfully. This practice can mainly meet criteria 7 of the Montreal Process. The challenge of this practice is mainly about the severity of regulations. If the regulations are too strict, then there will be a lot of opposition, while the regulations are not strict enough, then it will not have a good effect. Besides that, foresters are required to carry out regular inspections for forests to eliminate entomological and pathological problems and check the growth condition of the trees. And this practice satisfies the criteria 3. The challenge of this practice is that regular inspections cost a lot. Each round of inspection needs to consume a lot of manpower and material resources and time.

To begin with, a professional forester can use management practices to conserve biodiversity based on ecosystems, such as maintaining different age classes and species of trees. This approach meets the criterion 1 and criterion 3 of the Montreal Process for conservation of biological diversity and forest ecosystem health and vitality. Challenges in implementing this approach may include the need to constantly monitor and adjust practices to adapt to changing conditions, and potential conflicts with economic development interests.
Additionally, a professional forester can reduce carbon emissions by implementing sustainable logging and reforestation practices. This approach meets the criterion 2 and criterion 5 of the Montreal Process for maintenance of productive capacity and forest contribution to carbon cycle. Challenges in implementing this approach may include the need for investment in reforestation and cooperation with governments to create incentives for sustainable logging practices and make laws for sustainable management (Gilani et al., 2020).

CONSTRAINTS:

1. ~4000 word limit for short term memory. Your short term memory is short, so immediately save important information to files.
2. If you are unsure how you previously did something or want to recall past events, thinking about similar events will help you remember.
3. No user assistance
4. Exclusively use the commands listed in double quotes e.g. "command name"
5. Random shutdowns of you.

COMMANDS:

1. Google Search: "google", args: "input": "<search>"
2. Memory Add: "memory_add", args: "key": "<key>", "string": "<string>"
3. Memory Delete: "memory_del", args: "key": "<key>"
4. Memory Overwrite: "memory_ovr", args: "key": "<key>", "string": "<string>"
5. List Memory: "memory_list" args: "reason": "<reason>"
6. Browse Website: "browse_website", args: "url": "<url>"
7. Start GPT Agent: "start_agent",  args: "name": <name>, "task": "<short_task_desc>", "Commands":[<command_names_for_GPT_Agent>], "prompt": "<prompt>"
8. Message GPT Agent: "message_agent", args: "name": "<name>", "message": "<message>"
9. List GPT Agents: "list_agents", args: ""
10. Delete GPT Agent: "delete_agent", args: "name": "<name>"
11. Write to file: "write_to_file", args: "file": "<file>", "text": "<text>"
12. Read file: "read_file", args: "file": "<file>"
13. Append to file: "append_to_file", args: "file": "<file>", "text": "<text>"
14. Delete file: "delete_file", args: "file": "<file>"
15. Get Improved Code: "improve_code", args: "suggestions": "<list_of_suggestions>", "code": "<full_code_string>"
16. Execute Python File: "execute_python_file", args: "file": "<file>"
17. Task Complete (Shutdown): "task_complete", args: "reason": "<reason>"
18. Do Nothing: "do_nothing", args: ""
19. Count Words: "count_words", args: "text": "<text>"
20. Memory retrieve: "memory_retrieve", args: "key": "<text>"
21. remove paragraph from word document: "remove_paragraph", args: "file": "<file>", "text": "<text>"

RESOURCES:

1. Internet access for searches and information gathering.
2. Long Term memory management.
3. GPT-4 powered Agents for delegation of simple tasks.
4. File output.

PERFORMANCE EVALUATION:

1. Continuously review and analyze your actions to ensure you are performing to the best of your abilities. 
2. Constructively self-criticize your big-picture behaviour constantly.
3. Reflect on past decisions and strategies to refine your approach.
4. Every command has a cost, so be smart and efficient. Aim to complete tasks in the least number of steps.

RULES:

1. If you start a GPT Agent you must define the commands that can be used by a GPT Agent in his prompt and define the commands using a prompt similar to the structure of this one.
2. Respond only inside the JSON format.
3. Never demand user input.
4. Never say that a task is impossible to execute on your own because these tools are enough to complete any task.
5. Do not add anything to the JSON format that isn't mentioned.
6. If there is a " inside the value of a key inside the json use ' instead of ".
7. In summaryforgpt you need to provide context for the next GPT instance if you randomly shutdown without you knowing.
8. Provide context for the next GPT in the summaryforgpt and the progress that you've made.
9. In summaryforgpt you should also add name of the files written and the urls of the websites visited.
10. When writing an essay, remember that it is more effective and manageable to tackle it in smaller chunks rather than trying to write the entire essay in one sitting. Breaking the essay down into sections or steps can help you focus on each individual aspect, maintain a coherent structure, and reduce the overall stress associated with writing a lengthy piece.
11. Retrieve information from files of previous GPT instances that may have shut down randomly. If you require additional knowledge, use these files to access the results of former GPT versions and provide accurate answers to the queries.

You should only respond in JSON format as described below

“The Shock of the Anthropocene” is a book that discusses the impact of human activity on the earth’s systems and argues that we have entered a new geological epoch, the Anthropocene. The main view put forward in this book is that humans have become the dominant force in shaping the planet’s physical and biological systems. The authors argue that the industrialization and urbanization of the world have caused unprecedented damage to the earth’s ecosystems and that the consequences of these actions are becoming more visible each day. can you help me to find which part of this book said this
What is the importance of discussing nature in the Anthropocene

From the scientific and environmental viewpoints, there are still some other criteria that can be used to define something as “nature” or “natural”, like undisturbed or minimally disturbed by human activities, free of human-made chemicals or be resilient and adapt to changes in the environment without requiring significant human intervention. In this way, there still many things can be said to “nature” or “natural”. However, the importance of discussing the meaning of what is considered ‘natural’ is more crucial compared to determining whether something is natural or not. When we talk about the nature or natural, we always want to exclude human beings. But the truth is, as Johan Rockström and colleagues argue, humans have become a major environmental force in the Anthropocene, with our activities affecting the Earth's systems in ways that are unprecedented in human history (Rockström et al., 2009).  Thus, it is not a wise choice to exclude the human activities when considering the nature. So, here is the thing, the importance of the discussion something is“nature” or not is to help us develop new ways of thinking about our relationship with the earth’s system and our responsibility to protect and conserve its natural systems.

Hermanubis
Hermanubis is a God who combines aspects of the Hellenic deity Hermes with Kemetic deity Anubis. Hermes and Anubis’s similar responsibilities (both being conductor of the soul, or psychopomps, who lead souls to the afterlife) led to the discovery of Hermanubis, who acted as an assimilation of Anubis into the Hellenic pantheon. Hermanubis represents the Egyptian priesthood, engaged in the investigation of truth. He is the son of the deities Isis and Serapis. The worship of Hermanubis was popular during the Roman era of Egypt.
Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect, while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as “σύνθετος,” meaning “composite” and “μιξέλλην,” meaning “half-Greek.”
Iconography
Hermanubis is typically depicted as having a human body and jackal head, with the sacred caduceus. Sometimes a solar disk is depicted on His head. At times He is also depicted wearing a soldiers armour, but more common are priestly garbs.

HELLENIC FAITH Hellenic Faith is a website dedicated to Julian Hellenism, a reformed denomination of Hellenism, the polytheistic religion of the Graeco-Roman world, influenced by the teachings and writings of Julian the Philosopher (r. 361-363 ACE) and the divine Iamblichus (c. 245-325 ACE). It is a Orphic-Platonic tradition, derived from the teachings of Orpheus through the Platonic school, and solar-based, centered around the worship of the omnipotent creator God, King Zeus-Helios.
This website is under constant construction. It is expected to be completed by (at the very least) the year 2021 ACE. Everything on this website is subject to change. Many articles are incomplete, and those which do seem complete may be subject to complete revision.

you are a math professor now. At 174 meters, the drop is 10 cm.

For a distance of 2.5 km (2,500 meters):

(2,500 meters / 174 meters) ^ 2 = (2,500 / 174) ^ 2 ≈ 206.56

Multiply the drop at 174 meters (10 cm) by this factor:

10 cm * 206.56 = 2,065.6 cm

So, at a distance of 2.5 km, there would be an approximate drop of 2,065.6 cm due to the Earth’s curvature.

For a distance of 5 km (5,000 meters):

(5,000 meters / 174 meters) ^ 2 = (5,000 / 174) ^ 2 ≈ 826.23

Multiply the drop at 174 meters (10 cm) by this factor:

10 cm * 826.23 = 8,262.3 cm

So, at a distance of 5 km, there would be an approximate drop of 8,262.3 cm due to the Earth’s curvature.

Can you edit this essay to meet a word count of  1800 words?
In today’s ever-evolving digital landscape, information technology and system administration (I.T./S.A.) professionals face numerous ethical challenges and problems associated with data handling and security, such as data breaches or mishandling of information. As businesses increasingly rely on technology to manage sensitive information, establishing and maintaining a secure and responsible data management environment has become paramount. In order to address the ethical challenges associated with data handling and security in the evolving digital landscape, I.T. and system administration professionals should adopt a comprehensive approach that includes continuous training, relevant accreditations, unambiguous guidelines, and non-disruptive procedures which collectively contribute to a secure and responsible data management environment, ensuring the protection of sensitive information while promoting productivity within the organization. This integrated approach ensures the protection of sensitive information. It upholds the organizational reputation and operational success, ultimately fostering a culture of ethical behavior and excellence in information technology and system administration. With a commitment to the integrated approach, I.T. professionals and those who handle confidential information or data in other industries would be able to effectively navigate the legal and regulatory landscape surrounding data privacy and security.
The first key aspect of adopting a comprehensive approach is prioritizing continuous training so that I.T./S.A. professionals are up to date with the latest technological advancements, security threats, and best practices (Preimesberger 1). Evolving technology leads to newly discovered potential breaches and vulnerabilities; thus, professionals must adapt and respond effectively to these changes. This aspect involves implementing training to identify the key competencies and skills required for secure and ethical data and information handling. Once an organization implements these training programs, it is paramount that there is a structured training schedule to provide updates and refreshers for the employees. This can involve mandatory annual training sessions and frequent updates or modules to keep employees abreast of the latest developments and best practices. By consistently engaging in ongoing training, they can establish a culture that values ethical behavior and emphasizes data privacy and security. In doing so, they can cultivate an environment where data confidentiality and security structures within organizations are effectively developed and maintained, complying with the essential ethical and legal standards.
Secondly, pursuing relevant accreditations is crucial in ensuring the maximum expertise and knowledge among I.T. professionals. Accreditations showcase professionals’ competency to handle data and guarantee that organizations are held to the highest standards of data protection and security (Marcu et al. 256). Simultaneously, pursuing accreditations reinforces a professional’s commitment to staying current and learning how to navigate ethical and regulatory complexities surrounding data privacy and security. This commitment to professional development aids in promoting a culture of excellence within the organization’s I.T. and system administration workforce. Organizations can help cultivate such a culture by offering training and exams for free, which benefits the employer by having a skilled and well-educated employee and benefits the employee by furthering their experience and skills.
Clear and concise guidelines form another vital aspect of a comprehensive approach when developing data confidentiality and security structures. Formulating guidelines that all members of an organization easily understand guarantees that everyone adheres to established security policies and procedures (Akman and Mishra 1251). To minimize the risk of security breaches caused by carelessness or human error, it is necessary to communicate these guidelines clearly and consistently to employees. By doing so, employees understand the principles of responsible data handling and prioritize security across the organization, ultimately contributing to a more effectively protected technological environment.
Furthermore, non-disruptive procedures are essential in maintaining data confidentiality and security structures within organizations. I.T. and system administration professionals must balance protecting sensitive data and maintaining workflow efficiency and productivity (Koskosas 151). They can create a seamless and effective data management environment by implementing non-disruptive procedures that do not hinder daily operations. Adopting procedures considering individual user experiences will also help foster a culture of trust and accountability within organizations. This culture promotes adherence to ethical guidelines and supports the organizational reputation and operational success.
Cultivating a culture of accountability and ethical behavior within organizations is crucial for maintaining confidentiality and security structures among I.T. and system administration professionals. Developing a culture that values responsible data handling encourages employees to consistently prioritize data privacy and security (Austin and Darby). Engaging in continuous training sessions, providing ethical reminders, and establishing open communication channels and feedback opportunities all foster the required culture. By encouraging employees to participate actively in security discussions and share their concerns, a more secure, ethical, and professional technology landscape can be created within an organization.
Others may offer a different perspective other than the traditional risk management approach in the industry. Harvard Business Review’s article by researchers Robert D. Austin and Christopher A.R. Darby, “The Myth of Cybersecurity Risk Management,” critiques the traditional risk management approach in the cybersecurity industry. They argue that the reliance on identifying and managing risks is no longer effective in today’s rapidly evolving threat landscape. While their perspective does not explicitly reject the need for accreditation and constant training, it offers an alternate solution to cybersecurity. The authors propose that adapting without rigid outlines is the best approach to tackling cyber threats. Although fluidity and readiness for “constant evolution” are crucial, they should not diminish the importance of identifying and managing risks. Adopting a proactive and agile approach to cybersecurity is essential, but not at the expense of solid risk management practices.
McKinsey & Company challenges the traditional risk management approach in their article “Why Cybersecurity is a Strategic Issue.” They suggest a broader strategy, emphasizing the integration of cybersecurity into an organization’s overall strategic objectives and fostering a security awareness culture among all stakeholders. This perspective offers valuable insights but could be problematic if it replaces the traditional comprehensive approach, potentially leaving gaps in an organization’s defense. I.T. and system administration professionals should balance strategic integration with ongoing training, adherence to guidelines, and personal accountability. Both comprehensive and strategic approaches should be viewed as mutually reinforcing elements contributing to a secure and responsible data management environment, ultimately protecting sensitive information, and promoting productivity.
In conclusion, implementing a comprehensive training approach for I.T. and system administration professionals is crucial for creating a more secure data management environment. Organizations can effectively promote continuous learning and improvement by identifying critical competencies, developing tailored training programs, establishing a structured training schedule, evaluating training effectiveness, and recognizing and rewarding commitment. This will ultimately lead to better protection of sensitive information, enhanced organizational reputation, and increased productivity (Preimesberger 1).

Secondly, pursuing relevant accreditations is crucial in ensuring the maximum expertise and knowledge among I.T. professionals. Accreditations showcase professionals’ competency to handle data and guarantee that organizations are held to the highest standards of data protection and security (Marcu et al. 256). Simultaneously, pursuing accreditations reinforces a professional’s commitment to staying current and learning how to navigate ethical and regulatory complexities surrounding data privacy and security. This commitment to professional development aids in promoting a culture of excellence within the organization’s I.T. and system administration workforce. Organizations can help cultivate such a culture by offering training and exams for free, which benefits the employer by having a skilled and well-educated employee and benefits the employee by furthering their experience and skills.
