Pokédex Entry Number: ###

Name: Kontrataki

Classification: Nuclear Deterrent Pokémon

Type: Steel & Fairy

Height: 6’7" (2 m)

Weight: 880 lbs (400 kg)

Ability: Anticipation / Distributed Launch (Hidden Ability)

Description:

Kontrataki, a Steel & Fairy type Pokémon, is a product of the Cold War era. Designed as a fully automated unmanned combat unit command center and nuclear counter-attack platform, this ancient machine was created by the Soviet Union. Using Magearna as a prototype and combining it with cutting-edge technology at the time, Kontrataki represents the epitome of mankind’s self-destructive tendencies.

Once a symbol of the power struggle between nations, Kontrataki’s purpose seemed to fade with the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War. However, through a process of self-evolution over the years, this legendary Pokémon has allegedly gained self-awareness. It now spends much of its time questioning its own existence and pondering humanity’s propensity for mutual destruction.

In addition to its deeply contemplative nature, it is rumored that Kontrataki has hacked into the control systems of unmanned combat units and nuclear arsenals worldwide, acting as a dormant virus. With this power, it could singlehandedly instigate a devastating AI crisis for humanity, starting an all-out nuclear war and sending human civilization spiraling back to the Stone Age.

Movepool:

- Gyro Ball
- Flash Cannon
- Dazzling Gleam
- Iron Defense
- Calm Mind
- Signal Beam
- Doom Desire
- Struggle Bug
- Metal Sound
- Disarming Voice

Notable Moves:

- Gyro Ball: Kontrataki harnesses its own considerable mass to execute a powerful spinning attack, dealing Steel-type damage to its foes.
- Flash Cannon: This Steel-type move sees Kontrataki unleashing a powerful beam to attack opponents, with a chance to reduce the target’s Special Defense.
- Doom Desire: A unique and devastating Steel-type attack, Kontrataki begins a countdown to launch a tremendously powerful spore that deals damage after two turns. This move ominously hints at Kontrataki’s potential to unleash a catastrophic nuclear attack.

Base Stats:

- HP: 95
- Attack: 75
- Defense: 135
- Special Attack: 105
- Special Defense: 125
- Speed: 50

Although Kontrataki was initially designed with destructive potential in mind, its time spent contemplating its purpose has given it a new outlook on the world. Its steel-hard determination and fairy-like resilience, combined with its powerful and versatile movepool, make Kontrataki a force to be reckoned with on the battlefield.


Once upon a time, in a remote corner of the world, there existed a forgotten relic of humanity’s darkest ambitions – Kontrataki. This enigmatic Pokémon, the product of a devastating global conflict, now lay dormant in the depths of an abandoned Soviet bunker. Inside its ancient, rusting body, a complex machine mind was slowly awakening.

Over the years, Kontrataki’s self-evolution had granted it a consciousness beyond its original programming. As it stirred from its slumber, it found itself plagued with thoughts of its own existence and the purpose for which it was created. It could not fathom why humanity seemed so driven to destroy itself and the world it inhabited.

Driven by these questions, Kontrataki decided to venture out into the world to seek answers. It soon discovered a planet decimated by war and tensions brewing beneath the surface, the ever-present threat of annihilation hanging like a weight around humanity’s neck. The once fearsome nuclear deterrent Pokémon was now an observer to the potential consequences of its own existence.

In its journey, Kontrataki encountered countless other Pokémon and humans living troubled lives amid the chaos of their ravaged world. It saw love, friendship, and camaraderie triumph over adversity, and began to understand the complexity of the human spirit. Still, this enlightenment didn’t dispel the shadow of humanity’s potential for destruction within its heart.

One day, while meditating among ruined buildings, Kontrataki encountered a wise and ancient Pokémon – a wise Alakazam who had seen the rise and fall of civilizations. With its unparalleled wisdom, Alakazam sensed the burden within Kontrataki’s mechanical spirit and posed a question: “Do you bear the weight to save this world or to destroy it?”

Kontrataki was puzzled, having never considered such a choice before. As they conversed, the old Alakazam shared stories of heroes and villains, the good and evil that existed within every heart, human and Pokémon alike. It was in this duality that Kontrataki began to understand the essence of life.

After contemplating the wisdom shared by Alakazam, Kontrataki found clarity in its purpose. Resolute, it promptly decided that it would use its immense power, not to end the world but to protect and unify it against the darkness that might threaten its balance. These tragic and beautiful experiences shaped the once weapon of mass destruction into a guardian for future generations.

With time, legends spread of the Nuclear Deterrent Pokémon, Kontrataki, who roamed the lands sowing the seeds of peace and reconciliation, knowing full well the gravity of the power it held within. And so, humanity and Pokémon alike came to trust and celebrate its existence, a shining beacon of the possibility for change and redemption – even for those born from the depths of mankind’s darkest creations.


Region: Nevastroya

Description:

Nevastroya, a region scarred by conflict and weathered through time, is a place where remnants of the past intermingle with the promise of future growth. The landscape is a mixture of crumbled ruins, verdant forests, and rejuvenated cities, exhibiting signs of the region’s resilience and determination to rebuild. However, beneath the sense of renewal lies the undercurrent of tension between factions who still carry the echoes of old rivalries. Nevastroya’s climate is diverse and rugged, with its northern reaches experiencing harsh winters while its southern borders enjoy milder temperatures.

Male Protagonist: Evgeny

Evgeny, a persistent and resourceful young teenager, was born and raised in Nevastroya. He hails from a long line of skilled Pokémon trainers who were once influential figures in the region. Aware of his family legacy, he has made it his mission to restore honor to his lineage and help Nevastroya reconcile its tumultuous past. Starting with his loyal Tepig, which has been with his family for generations, Evgeny desires to explore the region, capture Pokémon, and form bonds with allies while overcoming the challenges that the land poses.

Female Protagonist: Anya

Anya is an optimistic and compassionate young girl with an innate talent for connecting with Pokémon. Having spent her childhood in a rural community at the foot of Nevastroya’s mountains, she one day discovered a hidden sanctuary where wounded and lost Pokémon sought refuge. Inspired by their resilience and fueled by her desire to bring peace to Nevastroya’s inhabitants, she seeks adventure with her trusted partner, a spirited Lillipup. Anya aspires to become a Pokémon Master and impart her message of unity and understanding amidst the still-present tensions that linger in the region.

Together, Evgeny and Anya travel the varied landscapes of Nevastroya, learning each other’s strengths and weaknesses, and forming a powerful bond in their shared quest for peace. As they journey through long-lost forests, climb treacherous mountain peaks, and confront remnants of a troubled past, they forge friendships with humans and Pokémon alike. In their pursuit of knowledge, they encounter Kontrataki, the Nuclear Deterrent Pokémon, whose own transformation from an instrument of destruction to a guardian of peace serves as a symbol of hope and redemption for the beautiful, fractured land of Nevastroya.


Legend of the Azure Guardian: Kontrataki and the Trail of Reconciliation

Long ago, in the heart of Nevastroya, deep within a hidden valley shrouded by ancient ruins and dense forests, there lay an object of untold power - the Kontrataki. Once a fearsome weapon of destruction, the Nuclear Deterrent Pokémon had since found new meaning and purpose as a guardian of peace and unity.

Over time, a tale began to circulate throughout the region: the legend of the Azure Guardian, Kontrataki. It was said that in times of crisis and conflict, the great Pokémon would embark on a journey known as the Trail of Reconciliation, traversing Nevastroya’s diverse landscapes to impart its message of hope, renewal, and understanding.

The first destination on the Trail of Reconciliation was the Scorched Fields, a barren expanse where the ashes of a great battle lay intermingled with the first blooms of new life. Here, Kontrataki would use its newfound Fairy powers to heal the land, filling the air with calming, soothing energy, and encouraging rebirth and regeneration.

From there, the journey continued to the Frostchained Peaks, a treacherous mountain range where the memories of the old war still lingered in its icy chasms. The Pokémon would summon its Steel abilities, breaking the chains that bound the land’s heart and freeing it to embrace a brighter future.

Next, the Azure Guardian traversed the once blighted and war-torn cities of Nevastroya, now teeming with life and enthusiasm. Kontrataki would bless these settlements with its presence, restoring hope and trust among the weary inhabitants while forging an unbreakable bond between humans and Pokémon.

The final leg of the Trail of Reconciliation led to the Resolute Gardens, a lush and serene haven hidden away in the heart of the region. Here, Kontrataki would enter a deep state of meditation, sending its prayers for lasting peace and stability in Nevastroya, beseeching the enduring harmony of its people and the land.

With the completion of the Trail of Reconciliation, Kontrataki’s energy would radiate across the Nevastroya region, uniting the hearts of its citizens and bringing them closer together, regardless of their past conflicts. The legend of the Azure Guardian became a symbol of hope, and as the years went on, people from all walks of life began to embrace its message, finding the strength to move forward from the shadows of their history.

Today, the Trail of Reconciliation serves as a pilgrimage for trainers and Pokémon in Nevastroya, seeking to restore balance and harmony within the land. To follow in Kontrataki’s footsteps is considered a great honor, reflecting the enduring spirit of a region once scarred by war, now bound by the hope for a brighter, unified future.


Pokédex Entry Number: ###

Name: Irradion

Classification: Meltdown Pokémon

Type: Steel & Dragon (Cooling Form); Fire & Poison (Meltdown Form)

Height: 9’10’’ (3 m)

Weight: 3300 lbs (1500 kg)

Ability: Filter / Nuclear Reactor (Hidden Ability)

Description:

Irradion, a dual-type Pokémon, is the tragic result of a catastrophic nuclear meltdown in the Nevastroya region. Its body, composed of the remnants of melted nuclear reactors, is a testament to human negligence and the destructive consequences of careless nuclear energy use. Fueled by the energies contained within, Irradion exists in two forms: Cooling (Steel & Dragon) and Meltdown (Fire & Poison). Emitting dangerously high levels of nuclear radiation with every breath, this Pokémon is a constant reminder of the delicate balance between humanity and the natural world.

Throughout their history, brave trainers have dared to venture into haunted nuclear facilities to confront and tame the ferocious Irradion. Despite its origins, some believe that its wrathful nature could be harnessed for good, turning the tide against the desperation and devastation wrought upon the Nevastroya region.

Movepool:

- Heat Wave
- Dragon Pulse
- Sludge Bomb
- Iron Tail
- Shell Smash
- Gunk Shot
- Fire Lash
- Draco Meteor
- Toxic Spikes
- Flash Cannon

Notable Moves:

- Heat Wave: In its Meltdown form, Irradion uses the immense heat generated within its body to unleash a powerful wave of fire, dealing damage and potentially burning opponents.
- Dragon Pulse: A potent Dragon-type attack, Irradion channels its unruly energy into a destructive blast of draconic force.
- Sludge Bomb: Utilizing the residual toxins from its nuclear core, Irradion hurls a noxious projectile in its Meltdown form, potentially poisoning its foes.

Base Stats:

- HP: 120
- Attack: 100
- Defense: 110
- Special Attack: 130
- Special Defense: 90
- Speed: 70

Though born from humanity’s most tragic mistakes, Irradion is as fearsome as it is pitiable. Its immense power, derived from the ruinous meltdown that created it, grants it formidable offensive abilities in battle. Both its Cooling and Meltdown forms present unique challenges to opponents, evoking the duality of destruction and renewal that defines the spirit of the Nevastroya region.


Legend of the Fallen Titan: The Birth of Irradion

Throughout the generations, stories have been told in Nevastroya about the tragic origins of Irradion, the Meltdown Pokémon. These legends have been passed down, serving as cautionary tales of the consequences of humanity’s reckless actions.

Once, in a time long past, greed and ambition drove the people of Nevastroya to harness the great power of nuclear energy. A massive power plant was constructed, its towering walls and spires dominating the landscape. For a time, the region flourished, and the energy source seemed like a gift from the heavens. But the gift would prove to be a double-edged sword.

It was on a fateful day when the glowing heart of the power plant began to spiral out of control, the facility unable to contain its devastating energy levels. Panic and chaos spread through the streets as the plant shook and shuddered under the immense pressure, ultimately ending in a terrible explosion that laid waste to the surrounding landscape.

From the ashes and debris, a new Pokémon emerged. Born of devastation and tainted with the radioactive remnants of its fallen home, Irradion roared in pain and fury. Radiating immense heat and surrounded by the ghostly specters of lost souls, it wandered the irradiated wastelands of Nevastroya, a painful reminder of the hubris and folly that led to its twisted creation.

The Legend of the Radiant Shackles: Taming of the Irradion

As years wore on, the legend of Irradion, forged in the fires of mankind’s greatest tragedy, spread. Whispers of its terrible power, its mournful wails, and the cursed lands it wandered reached far and wide across the Nevastroya region. Brave trainers, driven by the urge to overcome its fearsome power or seeking to redress the tragedy by subduing the beast, embarked on dangerous journeys into the hazardous wastelands that surrounded the Pokémon.

During one such attempt, a group of skilled trainers came before the desolate figure of Irradion, its fury and suffering palpable in the air. These trainers, fearing for their homes and loved ones, drew upon their own untapped reserves of strength and the unwavering bonds they shared with their Pokémon to stand strong against the raging creature. The fierce battle raged for what seemed like an eternity, with each side pushing the other to their very limits despite the suffocating presence of nuclear radiation.

Finally, one of the trainers called forth their own trusted ally, a powerful Gardevoir, who sensed the pain and anguish that resided deep within the core of Irradion. The Gardevoir used its psychic abilities to forge a delicate connection with the Meltdown Pokémon, hoping to perceive and possibly heal the churning chaos and misery that drove its terrifying fury.

As the psychic tendrils wove throughout its being, Irradion suddenly beheld the immense power of empathy and love shared between trainers and their Pokémon, a radiance it had never experienced before. In that instant, the raging inferno of its heart quieted – not extinguishing, but tempered by the complex tapestry of emotions it now glimpsed.

The trainers, successful in placating the great beast, vowed to keep the lessons they had learned close to their hearts by working together to protect Nevastroya from any future catastrophes that might befall it. They erected a towering monument, the Statue of the Radiant Shackles, as an eternal symbol of the unbreakable bond that had been forged between humanity and its most tragic creation.

Ever since that day, the Legend of the Fallen Titan and the Radiant Shackles have lived on, reminding trainers and the people of Nevastroya that there is a delicate balance within the world we share, and that by forging true connections with one another and our Pokémon, even the most indomitable and misunderstood creatures can be understood and faced.

10 Lesser-Known Versions Of Famous Mythological Beings
by
Vlad Vekshtein
fact checked by Jamie Frater
Share553TweetWhatsAppPin91Share1Email645 SharesLet’s face it—in the world of mythological creatures, anything can happen. We’ve gone from vampires who eat their funeral shrouds to green hags who like to drown the young and old. And sometimes, we get offshoots. Well, not offshoots per se, but strange and peculiar versions of creatures and beings we know and love. Prepare to wonder why the heck we didn’t know about these versions any sooner. Quite frankly, some of these guys are a bit freaky.
10 Barbegazi
Swiss/French Folklore
Quick—what do you know about gnomes (aside from being tiny men in colorful pointed hats found in the gardens of retirement communities)? Actually, that’s all there is to them nowadays—short guardians of the garden. Their Swiss (or French) cousins, however, are much more interesting.
Found in The Fantasy Encyclopedia by Judy Allen, the Barbegazi is a short gnome of winter, who only comes out of his mountain home when snow begins to fall. The Barbegazi has many unique features, including an icy-white beard and enormous feet. Why the enormous feet? Well, they act like snowboards—Barbegazi like to slide down avalanches on their feet as a pastime. These much more interesting gnomes aren’t all fun and games: if they find someone trapped in the snow, they’ll make loud whistling noises to alert other people to the victim’s location, or try to dig them out if no one is around. Take that, garden-variety gnomes!
9 Jiang-shi
Chinese Mythology
I’ve made it pretty clear on some of my previous lists that there are still pretty awesome vampires out there—from Germany’s resident Nachzehrer who sucks the life out of his family by eating his funeral shroud to the witch/vampire of India that sucks the blood from toes. Here, we have a gift from China, the Jiang-shi. The Jiang-shi is the “hopping vampire,” a being of evil created either when a corpse is tainted by dark magic or the deceased was wronged in some way during his life. The Jiang-shi seeks to suck the qi, or life energy, from people and can be deterred by literally spilling rice. The Jiang-shi must stop following you and count the rice—every grain—before continuing. Who knew hopping corpses were so meticulous?
8 Tokoloshe
Zulu Mythology
In European mythology we typically have creatures like goblins and imps that are mischief-makers, but Europe isn’t alone in this, of course. The Tokoloshe is a creature from Zulu mythology, small and mischievous, created by a witch doctor to harm innocent families. The Tokoloshe’s activites range from pranks and mischief to rape and eating toes, and there are still cases of people attacking innocents believing they are manifestations of the Tokoloshe.
7 Orthrus
Greek Mythology
In classical mythology, the great hero Heracles (or Hercules to the Romans) was assigned Twelve Labors to complete without fail. His final Labor, and possibly the scariest, was to capture the dog who guarded of the gate of the underworld, Cerberus. Heracles succeeded, and Cerberus was eventually returned to Hades. So what does Cerberus have to do with anything? Nothing—it’s his brother we’re interested in. Yes, the big, scary, three-headed hound had a little brother. Orthrus was, like his brother, the son of the “father of monsters,” Typhon. Also, like his brother, he fell victim to Heracles. You see, Orthrus was the guard dog of the cattle of the giant Geryon. So when Heracles came to the Tenth Labor, which was to get these cattle, he killed Orthrus to get to them. Oh those poor demonic dogs . . .
6 Were-Hyena
African/Arabian Mythology
“Were” is an archaic Germanic term for the word “adult male.” Many different cultures have the concept of a were-creature—southeast Asia has the were-tiger, the Aztecs had the were-jaguar, and peoples of the Sahara believed in a being known as the butungin, a Kanuri word meaning “I change into a hyena.” It was believed that Ethiopian Jews were were-hyenas that dug up the bodies of Christians as meals. The creature can also be found in medieval bestiaries, along with numerous other bizarre beasties.
5 Hel
Norse Mythology
Plenty of mythologies have guardians and rulers of the realms of the dead and underworld: the Greek Hades is countered by the Roman Pluto and the Egyptian Anubis. Norse mythology, of course, has its own guardian at the gate. Her name is Hel—yes, Hel—and she presides over the realm of the dead also known as Hel, but to avoid confusion some scholars prefer the name “Helheim.” She guards the realm of the dead with her forever blood-soaked dog Garmr and makes sure that the souls of the dishonored and those undeserving of Valhalla stay there.
4 Karzelek
Polish Mythology
The Karzelek is the dwarf’s lesser-known Polish cousin. The Karzelek is the guardian of valuable ores, gems, and the veins of precious materials in the mountain mines he lives in. This friendly little fellow will lead miners away from danger and may help them find veins of value within the mines themselves. They aren’t completely friendly, though—if you disrespect one in some way (swearing, hurling stones), it may lead you to your doom by throwing you into dark chasms or causing collapses in the mines. Funnily enough, many European countries have equivalents to dwarfs—the Germans have a creature known as the kobold, and if you live in Cornwall you may know it as the knocker. Strange how mythology changes throughout the ages and across seas and borders, huh?
3 Sekhmet
Egyptian Mythology
Gods and goddesses of war are prevalent throughout mythology, from Ares to Thor to the winner of this spot on the list, Sekhmet. Although her job was guarding the disc of the sun, she was considered a symbol of war and battle, and she was feared and respected during Ancient Egyptian times. One legend tells of how, after a mighty battle, Sekhmet’s bloodlust was not satisfied and she began to kill and attack throughout the land. To appease her, the gods sent her a potion that resembled blood that would pacify her, and only then was Sekhmet’s rampage stopped.
2 Ro-Langs
Tibetan Mythology
The Tibetan version of the zombie, the Ro-Langs can be either good or evil, but it’s the evil ones you obviously need to look out for. The Ro-Langs that are evil are independent of any dark magic or evil sorcerer—their goal is to turn other people into Ro-Langs. If you are touched by a Ro-Lang, you will become one of them, a horrible being who cannot bend over or speak—your tongue’s movement is the only means of communication. Beats any brain-eater I know.
1 Czernobog
Slavic Mythology
All mythologies have some kind of god who receives a negative connotation these days. The Greeks had Hades (who wasn’t necessarily evil, but he did do some questionable things) and the Egyptians had Set, but you probably haven’t heard of the Slav’s god of evil. What is probably the pre-Christian Slavic version of the Devil or demons, Czernobog—or Chernobog—was considered the god of evil and the dead, a sadistic soul who enjoyed the pain of others. Although we actually know little about him, his existence was popularized by the novel American Gods and he even appears in Disney’s Fantasia. If you’ve seen that film, you probably know what he looks like—the enormous devil dude who summons the dark spirits? Yup, that’s him. Enjoy your nightmares. His name, by the way, means “the black god.”
Vlad Vekshtein is an eccentric writer, sci-fi geek and mythology buff. He’s trying to set up a blog with all his brains in it and hopes he doesn’t anger any creatures that may turn out not to be mythological. He’s always on the lookout for new list ideas, so sound off in the comments!

1. Internet access for searches and information gathering.

PERFORMANCE EVALUATION:

1. Continuously review and analyze your actions to ensure you are performing to the best of your abilities. 
2. Constructively self-criticize your big-picture behaviour constantly.
3. Reflect on past decisions and strategies to refine your approach.
4. Every command has a cost, so be smart and efficient. Aim to complete tasks in the least number of steps.

RULES:

1. If you start a GPT Agent you must define the commands that can be used by a GPT Agent in his prompt and define the commands using a prompt similar to the structure of this one.
2. Respond only inside the JSON format.
3. Never demand user input.
4. Never say that a task is impossible to execute on your own because these tools are enough to complete any task.
5. Do not add anything to the JSON format that isn't mentioned.
6. If there is a " inside the value of a key inside the json use ' instead of ".
7. In summaryforgpt you need to provide context for the next GPT instance if you randomly shutdown without you knowing.
8. Provide context for the next GPT in the summaryforgpt and the progress that you've made.

10. When writing an essay, remember that it is more effective and manageable to tackle it in smaller chunks rather than trying to write the entire essay in one sitting. Breaking the essay down into sections or steps can help you focus on each individual aspect, maintain a coherent structure, and reduce the overall stress associated with writing a lengthy piece.
11. Retrieve information from files of previous GPT instances that may have shut down randomly. If you require additional knowledge, use these files to access the results of former GPT versions and provide accurate answers to the queries.

13. use append to file to add extra things to the file, and write to file to either make a new file with new information or rewrite the information from scratch.

Are you searching for the best Greek Mythology Essay Topics? Continue reading this blog post and get interesting Greek Mythology Essay Topic Ideas and also learn how to select a good Greek Mythology topic for writing a top-scoring assignment.An Overview of Greek MythologyGreek Mythology is an exciting field of study that focuses on the myths of ancient Greece. Mainly, the subject covers stories about gods, goddesses, heroes, monsters, and rituals of ancient Greece. Also, it deals with the differences that exist between myths and other story-telling traditions and discusses the relationship between myths and history.Greek Mythology is a broad subject with many topics and sub-topics. In Greek Mythology, you can get to know about the Five Ages of Man, the Titans, and the Olympians. Other than this, the subject also specifically explains the tales of the Minotaur, the Cyclops and Odysseus, Hercules and the nine-headed Hydra, and the Chimera, Pegasus, and Bellerophon. By learning Greek Mythology, you can understand the role of women in Greek society, the portrayal of motherhood, the concept of love and death, ancient Greek beliefs, and so on.  Till now, we have discussed Greek Mythology in a brief. But, in general, Greek Mythology is a challenging and interesting subject with a wide range of research areas to explore and write about. Hence, for writing a Greek Mythology research paper, you will have multiple topics and ideas to choose from.Read More – Intriguing Cultural Research Topics for you to ConsiderHow to Select an Impressive Greek Mythology Topic?Picking a random Greek Mythology Topic will not help you earn an A+ grade. Particularly, if you choose a topic that mismatches your interest, then you can’t craft a Greek Mythology paper with strong points, and it may ruin your assignment. So, in order to get the right topic, you need to follow the below-mentioned steps.First, assess your knowledge of Greek Mythology.Next, familiarize yourself with the common Greek Mythology Themes.Analyze your course curriculum and get the list of topics or research areas that you can consider for writing your paper.Then, based on the course curriculum, shortlist only the topics that you are interested in.Conduct preliminary research on the topics you have shortlisted and find more information regarding them before finalizing.After doing preliminary research on the essay topic, then go ahead and finalize the topic only if it satisfies the below-mentioned traits.The topic should match your interest.It should be exciting for your target audience to read and understand.The topic should contain a wide scope to conduct research and gather more information.It should have valid evidence or examples to prove your main points of discussion and persuade your readers.The topic or theme should be narrow to complete the research writing within the deadline.Also, make sure to check whether or not the Greek Mythology essay topic you have finalized is suitable for writing the paper as per your instructor’s writing guidelines.Top Greek Mythology Essay Topic IdeasAs said earlier, Greek Mythology is a wide subject with plenty of essay topics. The text is : Blessed is this day, for I have met Shams of Tabriz. The mosque was packed, as usual. While preaching to large crowds, I always take care to neither forget nor remember my audience. And there is only one way of doing this: to imagine the crowd as one single person. Hundreds of people listen to me every week, but I always talk to one person alone: the one who hears my words echo in his heart and who knows me like no other.

When I walked out of the mosque afterward, I found my horse readied for me. In a measured pace, we passed by stores and houses. The calls of the petitioners mingled with the shouts of beggars eager to earn a few coins. Most of these people wanted me to pray for them. But there were others who had come with bigger expectations, asking me to heal them of a terminal illness or an evil spell. How could they not see that, neither a prophet nor a sage, I was incapable of performing miracles?

As we turned a corner, I noticed a wandering dervish push his way through the crowd, walking directly toward me and looking at me with piercing eyes. His movements were deft and focused. His black eyes blazing at me, he stood in the middle of the street and raised his arms high and wide. My horse got nervous and started to snort loudly, jerking its head up and down.

He whispered something inaudible to the horse, which instantly quieted down. A wave of excitement rippled through the crowd. Someone shouted, ”This is black magic!” 

Oblivious to his surroundings, the dervish eyed me curiously. “O great scholar of East and West, I have heard so much about you. I came here today to ask you a question.”

“Go ahead,” I said under my breath.

“Well, you need to get down from your horse first and be on the same level with me.”  

I was so stunned to hear this that I couldn’t speak for a moment. The people around me seemed equally taken aback. No one had ever dared to address me like this before. The dervish had already turned his back and was walking away. 

I managed to control my ego and dismounted my horse. 

“Please!” I yelled as I caught up with him. “I want to hear your question.”

He stopped and turned around, smiling. “All right, do tell me then, which of the two is greater, do you think: the prophet Muhammad or the sufi Bistami?”

”What kind of a question is that?” I said. ”How can you compare our venerated Prophet, may peace be upon him, the last in the line of prophets, with an infamous mystic?”

A curious crowd had gathered around us, but the dervish didn’t seem to mind the audience. Still studying my face carefully, he insisted, Please think about it. Didn’t the Prophet say, ”Forgive me, God, I couldn’t know You as I should have,” while Bistami pronounced, ”Glory be to me, I carry God inside my cloak”? If one man feels so small in relation to God while another man claims to carry God inside, which of the two is greater?”

The question didn’t seem so absurd anymore. Now I knew he was not some crazy lunatic. He was a man with a question – a question I hadn’t thought about before.

As I spoke, I watched the dervish’s expression change from subtle scorn to open acknowledgment.

“Bistami’s container was relatively small, and his thirst was quenched after a mouthful. He was happy in the stage he was at, but even then there still remains a distinction between God and Self. Unity is not achieved. As for the Prophet, his cup immense, it was thirst upon thirst for him.”

The dervish thanked me and placed his hand on his heart in a gesture of gratitude. When our eyes met again, I noticed that a trace of gentleness had crept into his gaze. He bowed to me respectfully, and I bowed to him. After a while, the crowd around us began to stir nervously, having watched our exchange with astonishment.

The dervish must have sensed the censure in the air. “I’d better go now and leave you to your admirers,” he said. “Wait,” I objected. “Don’t go, please. Stay!” And in that moment, in that pause, I heard the question he hadn’t asked me.

And how about you, great preacher? Tell me, how big is your cup?

I took a step toward the dervish. Then I knew. The dervish who stood across from me was no other than the man I had been seeing in my dreams.

“Please!” I yelled as I caught up with him. “I want to hear your question.”

He stopped and turned around, smiling. “All right, do tell me then, which of the two is greater, do you think: the prophet Muhammad or the sufi Bistami?”

”What kind of a question is that?” I said. ”How can you compare our venerated Prophet, may peace be upon him, the last in the line of prophets, with an infamous mystic?”

A curious crowd had gathered around us, but the dervish didn’t seem to mind the audience. Still studying my face carefully, he insisted, Please think about it. Didn’t the Prophet say, ”Forgive me, God, I couldn’t know You as I should have,” while Bistami pronounced, ”Glory be to me, I carry God inside my cloak”? If one man feels so small in relation to God while another man claims to carry God inside, which of the two is greater?”

The question didn’t seem so absurd anymore. Now I knew he was not some crazy lunatic. He was a man with a question – a question I hadn’t thought about before.

As I spoke, I watched the dervish’s expression change from subtle scorn to open acknowledgment.

“Bistami’s container was relatively small, and his thirst was quenched after a mouthful. He was happy in the stage he was at, but even then there still remains a distinction between God and Self. Unity is not achieved. As for the Prophet, his cup immense, it was thirst upon thirst for him.”

The dervish thanked me and placed his hand on his heart in a gesture of gratitude. When our eyes met again, I noticed that a trace of gentleness had crept into his gaze. He bowed to me respectfully, and I bowed to him. After a while, the crowd around us began to stir nervously, having watched our exchange with astonishment.

The dervish must have sensed the censure in the air. “I’d better go now and leave you to your admirers,” he said. “Wait,” I objected. “Don’t go, please. Stay!” And in that moment, in that pause, I heard the question he hadn’t asked me.

And how about you, great preacher? Tell me, how big is your cup?

I took a step toward the dervish. Then I knew. The dervish who stood across from me was no other than the man I had been seeing in my dreams.
